You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the trade-weighted s$neer trended up initially in h2 2001, reflecting in part a marked weakening of the us$ as data showed a sharper-than-expected slowdown in the us economy.\n                "}]

\\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the advance estimates released by the ministry of trade and industry today indicated that the singapore economy expanded by 0.8% on a quarter-on-quarter seasonally-adjusted basis in q3 2021, following a 1.4% contraction in the second quarter.\n                "}]

local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: cpi inflation is likely to be around 0% in 2009, before rising to 1-2% in 2010.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are expected to remain low, creating room for expansionary monetary policy."
}

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: domestic cost pressures, particularly stemming from a tight labour market, are likely to remain the primary source of inflation.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the source of inflation, but does not suggest any action or stance on monetary policy."
}

Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: amid moderate imported inflation and easing domestic cost pressures, the seasonally adjusted q-o-q rate of core inflation has declined to an annualised rate of 2.1% in q2.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: cpi inflation is expected to trend down for the rest of the year, coming in within the 1-1.5% range for 2001 as a whole.\n                "}]

economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: for 2005 and 2006 the advance gdp estimates released by the ministry of trade and industry showed that the singapore economy continued on a firm growth path in the third quarter of 2005, following broad-based expansion in h1.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the slightly negative output gap is projected to narrow further in h2 2024, even as underlying inflationary pressures gradually dissipate.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:42:44,571 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that underlying inflationary pressures are dissipating, which implies a reduction in inflationary pressures, creating room for expansionary monetary policy."
}

\n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the relative stability of the s$neer has reflected the strengthening of the s$ against the us$, offset by its weakening against a number of regional currencies.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: coe premiums could continue to rise in the short term as the market adjusts to the pending re-categorisation of coes.\n                "}]

of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: global capital expenditure has begun to turn up amid some strengthening in business sentiment, while improving labour market conditions should sustain final demand in the developed economies.\n                "}]

mas will continue to maintain the current policy of a modest and gradual appreciation of the s$neer policy band as announced in our statement of 12 april 2005.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:42:58,992 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a continuation of the current policy of a modest and gradual appreciation of the SGD, which suggests a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, we remain cautious about whether this is the start of a sustainable improvement, or merely a year-end seasonal pick-up in demand.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence expresses caution about the sustainability of an improvement, neither indicating optimism nor pessimism, and does not suggest any specific monetary policy action."
}

policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in comparison, modern services, such as information & communications, and selected domestic-oriented sectors should continue to provide support to the economy, underpinned by government spending and robust demand for healthcare and education services.\n                "}]

lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it depreciated over february to mid-march amid the broad-based strength of the us$.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: financial conditions are mostly favourable with inflation well-contained.\n                "}]

talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in april 2012, mas increased the slope of the s$neer policy band slightly.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "Increasing the slope of the S$NEER policy band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance, which is hawkish."
}

local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the easing of the s$ also reflected the rise of the us$ against major currencies.\n                "}]
