If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the output gap is expected to turn slightly positive.\n                "}]

policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: domestic-driven sectors, such as construction and related financing and real estate activities, will remain resilient.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the resilience of domestic-driven sectors, but does not suggest any action or stance related to monetary policy."
}

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the increase from 3.3% in q4 2023 was lower than expected.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: car prices could also rise further in response to the tight coe supply, especially if car de-registrations remain at current low levels.\n                "}]

Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in comparison, the domestic-oriented sectors should expand at a moderate pace, underpinned by sustained demand for healthcare and education services, as well as public infrastructure spending.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: while the global economy is expected to continue on its recovery path in 2022, it will do so at a more moderate pace than earlier projected.\n                "}]

economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this policy maintains the current level of the policy band, and there will be no re-centring of the band or change to its width.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: looking ahead, external inflationary pressures are likely to be sustained, largely due to higher oil prices.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that external inflationary pressures will be sustained, implying a need for a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability."
}

policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the near term, global final demand is expected to soften amid elevated interest rates.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests a softening of global final demand, which could lead to a decrease in inflationary pressures, creating room for expansionary monetary policy."
}

Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the forecasts for many regional economies have also been revised downwards following weak first quarter exports and gdp growth rates.\n                "}]

talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the resilience budget announced on 26 march, and the earlier unity budget, will help to preserve jobs, skills and firms’ know-how and capabilities.\n                "}]

Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, retail interest rates have remained stable.\n                "}]

Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: engineering.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the singapore economy has rebounded from the downturn and is expected to continue on its firm recovery path given the more favourable global economic .\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests a positive economic outlook, implying that the monetary policy can be more accommodative to support the recovery."

\n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: we do not expect the oil price shock to lead to further increases in consumer prices beyond their one-off impact.\n                "}]

"justification": "The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy."
}

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are
